title: The Anxious Generation
content: Book: The Anxious Generation

title: Entertainment Is Experience Blocking
content:
# Entertainment Is Experience Blocking

This is not directly form the book but I think entertainment might be "experience blocking" in the book it states how phones and tablets became experience blockers but that is not the case. It is the activities on these devices (primarily entertainment) that is experience blocking. Maybe I think this way because I leverage my computer a lot--via programming.

title: Boiled Into Technological Dependency
content:
# Boiled Into Technological Dependency

Like the parable about boiling a frog in water (which isn't actually true). People have been "boiled" into more and more technological dependency. This comes to me when thinking about [[dumbphones]] and the rejection of having "the best thing".

title: Humans Being Synchronous Fosters Relationships
content:
# Humans Being Synchronous Fosters Relationships

Humans being synchronous fosters relationships. It develops trust. An example is a parent and their child. The parent interacts with the child in a serve-and-return manner. The parent makes faces at the baby and the baby makes faces back, in a game of some sorts. When humans move together they trust each other more. This is why dancing to music is such a good way for people to bond. [[relationships]]

That is why being synchronous (such as a phone call) will make you feel more connected. I should try and call people more to feel more connected to them.

[[parenting]]

title: Puberty Impact On Brain
content:
# Puberty Impact on Brain

[[parenting]]
During pubtery a child's brain is quite sensitive to changes, this means one should be weary about the experiences the child experiences during this time.

title: Dumbphones
content:
[[article]]

# Dumbphones

Smartphones but dumb. They provide the essential functions of a phone (communication over distance), having some additional features (gps, notes, calculator), without the "smarter features" (such as "high performant applications" or "entertainment"). They are harder to use and help "[[reject convenience]]"

I think getting it is going to improve my life. I have gotten a glimpse of life without constant stimulation a few weeks ago when me and my roommates have formed a pact to use our phones less. I remember the feeling I had during the days of clarity in thought and [[intention]] in my actions. I have lost that a little bit because I had a bit of a habit of using laptop before bed, watching videos, masturbating, listening to music. This caused me to not go to bed. As of now, I am going to Madison Wisconsin and I want to make a large change to set myself up for a very goal-oriented summer. I have a lot of good momentum and in a much better mental position.

I believe using a dumb-phone will help me reclaim even more of this thought and enforce to myself and my self-concept I am serious.

### How it makes me think about others

I have a little bt of a nagging feeling that technology addiction has snuck up on us. Every year a new phone is annouced and people get it because it is better, faster, more storage, but people never think about why they want those features. Sure they might want it because it is easier to use, but that is akin to a smoker getting a a more ergonomic pack of cigareets to minimize the time between opening the box and the cigareet entering his mouth. It is my belief phone mindless technology usage is harmful and I am getting off of this by using a dumb phone.

Even now, I am not using my phone (because I have had a great habit of using it less, and I am writing instead. I am creating, using my brain, doing sometthing valuable.)

Using a dumbphone makes you an "independent thinker". I remember me being in high school and the teacher asked if anyone had an android. I was the only one in my class, but now I won't even have a smart phone. This makes me feel proud of myself, but I need to be warry of doing something just for the sake of being different.

title: Cost Of Entertainment Is Opportunity Cost
content:
# Cost of Entertainment Is Opportunity Cost

There is a huge opportunity cost of entertainment that most people never think about. They only think about the in-the-moment pleasure they gain from indulging in enteertainment instead of what else they are missing out on by being entertained. I think this is a huge, unseen tragedy.

title: Social Media Is A Conformity Engine
content:
# Social Media Is a Conformity Engine

Social media is a conformity engine, you see other people and see how their doing and you follow this. This explains my own behavior, I would copy what the people I watched did. I would play the games they played, I would pick up on the same language as them.
WOOW! Can I use this to my benefit?

Suppose I want to adopt behavior X, I want to adopt this belief but I don't already do so. One way of doing this is to fill my experiences with evidences that support belief X. [[beliefs-to-change]]

title: Greetings Make People Feel Closer
content:
# Greetings Make People Feel Closer

Beceause synchrnoous, face-to-phase, physical interactions and rituals create communion and trust, that is why people shake hands and have various other gestures. Not doing that would make people feel less communal. [[humans-being-synchronous-fosters-relationships]]

title: Play Should Be Free
content:
# Play Should Be Free

Play should be free with a child, it should be self driven, embodied, outside, with children of mixed ages.

title: Rites Of Passage
content:
# Rites of Passage

In most societies there are rites of passage so people know their new roles.

This is interesting to me because it shows that we have less autonomy. It shows the impact culture has more prescisely. For example, rites of passage tell you \*as the agent) your new roles (as a woman or man in the society). when yo uare toled these roles, you enact onto them. This is why ceremonies are imporant. They don't make ayo you feel different, but you embody different roles.

title: Fragmented Attention
content:
# Fragmented Attention

Technology usage causes fragmented attention by a device asking for your attention multiple times per hour.

title: Children Are Wired To Play
content:
# Children Are Wired to Play

As a part of growing up children are automatically wires to play. "play is the work of childhood". From the perspective of evolutionary biology, children are wired to play because it helpsfoster social relationships and dynamics. It also allows them to master motor movements. At every stage of development there are different types of play. Babies are played with in a simple way, using the babies limied motor movements. gnce the baby is able to walk, it can interact with others of a similar age group. They can then play "predator and cooperation games" whichare sports, hide-and-seek, tag. Then when they go into middle school they learn social games, about teasing and joking.

Hunans enjoy playing sports because we are evolved to enjoy to play them, it mimics hunting.

The purpose of childhood is to mimic adulthood but with less stakes

[[play-should-be-free]]

title: Sleep Deprivation
content:
# Sleep Deprivation

Sleep deprivation is caused directly by having something stimulating before going to bed. It causes truncated sleep times, longer onset to sleep, and more disturbances. To improve sleep, prevent the usage of stimulating activities (such as music, videos, social medias, interactions, etc.) 1 hour before bed.

title: Conforming
content:
# Conforming

Children have to learned to conform as a way of adopting the culture around them. This is called confromity attraction. It is positiive because it allows a child to adopt the culture of where they are, which is socially advantageous. This is why it is extremely important as a parten to ensure the "culture" (other kids) are doing what you wnt to do. So whoever parents your children is not only you, but the parents (better say experiences) of the other children. [[parenting]]

[[social-media-is-a-conformity-engine]]

content:

Storu set in the future where there is ah andicapper general that ensures everyone is the exact same.

title: So Good They Cant Ignore You
content: Book: So Good They Cant Ignore You

title: Control Requires Capital
content:
# Control Requires Capital

There's an idea in this book that control requires capital meaning that if you want to have a career that gives you a lot of control then you need to acquire career capital in order to get that control.

title: Difficulty Popularity Graph
content:
# Difficulty Popularity Graph

The more difficult it is to do or get something (more time, and effort) the less people would have done it. There are HUGE gaps in this, though, after every "mandatory-ish" training. To get from the middle 50 percent to the middle 75 percent takes more effort than 75 to 99. I think this is the case because a lot of people have done college or high school, so they have those skills, a lot have done coding boot camps or read papres. Always try to do something hard. This is th eprnicples.

Mental strain is good for you, it is something to prpouse, not avaid.

title: Craftsman Mindset
content:
# Craftsman Mindset

Deliberate practice is the metric you want to maximize for. By maximizing deliberate practice you will become so good they cant ignore you.

A vibrant image from the book is that of Jordan, the bluegrass player. Every day he spends 3-4 hours practciing etremely diffeDifficult chords. This is painful and he is working at his limit. By doing this every day for a decode he becomes an outlier [[outliers]].

Focusing on the clear metric of success--whatever that be in your field--is all you need to be successful. Don't worry about this or that. Focus on the essential [[essentialism]]

Focusing on the output you do and nothing else is called this craftsman mindset. For the feild of music a poweful idea is that of "the tape doesn't lie". It shows exactly how you good you practiced and nothing else matters. In programming, it could be that "your code doesn't lie" or "your algorithm doesn't lie". In terms of finance, it could be your deals don't lie.

ACTION: Find what the "obvious" metric of high quality is and maximize it.

The author has an interesting idea, that is to keep track of the amount of deliberate practice he works on every week. This mentis helpful for a couplen of reasons. One of them is that this metric is all in his cnotrol.

### When does the craftsman mindset fail?

he craftsman mindset won't grant you a great career if the following aren't met. [[traits-that-define-great-work]]

- The job doesn't allow mastery. Few opportunities to work
- The job doesn't have impact. It is on something you don't think matters in the world or actively harms the world
- You work with people you don't like

[[drive]]
metadata: {"file_path": "/home/matth/notes/resources/books/so-good-they-cant-ignore-you/craftsman-mindset.md", "book_title": "So Good They Cant Ignore You", "author": "", "rating": null, "status": "", "tags": [], "book_directory": "so-good-they-cant-ignore-you", "note_type": "craftsman-mindset"}

title: Finding A Mission
content:
The idea of finding a mission is similar to the principle of exploration one should do exploration if you do not know what you want to do specifically you should do a systematic exploration .

Something that's about the book is a story by a student who wanted to go back to grad school. However when she went to grad school she did not find herself to be very passionate about it she did not feel a mission that her life was revolving around So that leads to the question how you can actually find a mission that you should revolve your life around .

The author thinks finding a compelling missian is only possible in the adjacent possible in your field. Why is this the case?

Because you can only find a compelling mission at the adjacent possible, it is a smart move to try and get there extremely quickly.

Q: What cutting edge field do I want to get to? What is the adjacent possible I want to discover?

Having career capital is necessary, not just sufficient, to have a mission. This makes very intuitive sense, because a part of having a mission is the uniqueness that you have in it. If you don't have that uniqueness, and anyone in the world can do your mission, why are you doing it? [[ikigai]]

PRINCIPLE: You should gain career capital above all else

title: Career Capital Theory Of Great Work
content:
- The traits that define great work are rare and valuable.This is a theory posed in this book that states:
- Because these are highly saught after, you need to offer something valuable to get a career like this
- In order to becomes this valuable, you should adopt an intentional mindset of increasing your vaule for the career ([[career-capital]])

title: Ask Questions Down To Fundamentals
content:
# Ask Questions Down to Fundamentals

This is an idea that came up while reading "so good they cant ignore you". That idea comes from an example where there was a blogger that would write blogs and he would try to optimize his metrics, shower his readers with appreciation, etc. but he missed the mark. In order to write a good blog, you need to identify exactly what you want to give your readers. The typical reader wants something of value from you, like an insight or inspiration, so you need to dig down and find this "principle" of the field.

title: Adjacent Possible
content:
There's a story from the book that comes from another book called [[Where Good Ideas Come From]]. In this book there are actually a lot of examples of where people from several places discover the same thing so for example people from four different countries identified sunspots in the year 1611 Oxygen was isolated independently in 1772 and 1774.

why did these simultaneous discoveries happen Well these big ideas are often discovered in the adjacent possible adjacent possible is an idea where in order for you to get to a new idea you need to So that's why these ideas are only capable of being seen was other ideas are popularized

New, big ideas only yhappen when you take existing ideas and jiggle them into a new shape.

title: Dream Job Elixer
content:
# Dream Job Elixer

Dream job elixer is what you want in your job. It is highly related to the principles in [[drive]].

### Control

Having more control is what you want. In an ideal job, you want a good combination of control, pristige, passion, money, but be conscious of the balance. It might be better to become a free-lance software developer then a VP. But in order to make this decision, you need the career capital to afford it. to be a free-lance software developer

#### Vying for Control w/o capital

Vying for control without career capital is a mistake, and you will end up homeless like the yoga woman.

#### Wanting Control Means Resistance

In the book, there is a story of Lulu, who is a freelancer. Everytime she tried to gain more control there was always more resistence. People want to control you.

title: Career Capital
content:
# Career Capital

Career capital is all of the skills, networks, knowledge, and assets you have. The higher your career capital in one field is, the more successful you'll be in that field and the more opportunity you'll have.

Career capital:

- Skills (proof of skills)
- Knowledge
- Network
- Credentials?

title: Deliberate Practice
content:
# Deliberate Practice

Deliberate practice should be a daily routine.

Q: How can I apply deliberate practice to my own work?

When it comes to deliberate pracitce the author talks about him doing delibmerate practice, which was reading a paer and understading it fully.
REFLECTION: Think about this in relateion to my time in 598KKH

title: Control Creates Resistence
content:
# Control Creates Resistence

In your career whenever you want to gain more control that typically is met with some resistance which is in general because people want to be able to control you and tell you what to do. you don't want to do this of course so that creates this conflict in order to get through this you need to obtain enough career capital so that you can do what you want to do .

Once people want to pay you for what you want to do or once other people have given you feedback that you can do what you want to do that you can gain more economy .

### Law of Financial Viablitiy

when deciding whether to follow an appealing pursuit that will introduce more control into your work life seek evidence of whether people are willing to pay for it if you find this evidence continue if not move on

title: Alex Berger Career Capital Story
content:
Story of Alex Berger, he was someone that wanted to try to get into the TV industry. It is aparently very difficult to get into because everyone wants to get in. After 2 years of trying to master his craft(which in the TV industry is mastering writing his sccripts), he took charge of opportunities and got a lucrative job.

    !t is important to notee that you can only take charge of opportunities if you have enough career capital to take them on. Another thing that's Important to note is he was able to work in the industries where he could see exactly what matters to be successful as a television guy he moved careers and jobs just so that he could be closer to what real people do

title: Finding A Mission Doesn'T Require A Lot Of Direction
content:
# Finding a Mission Doesn't Require a Lot of Direction

People that are currently on a good path, working on their life's mission, definitely did not have a straight path for this

In the example of Paradis, she wanted to study math, then bio, then she went on a trip and learned more about biollogical anthropolgy.

The general idea is that [[your-true-calling-doesn't-exist]]

Q: What are other equample of ppl that were at the cutting edge of their fields and _then_ found their missions.

title: Act Small Think Big
content:
# Act Small Think Big

This is an idea in the book, you should think "narrowly" by just focusing on the narrow niche you are in, and then act big once you gain enough career capital to identify a mission.
